High-density lipoprotein cholesterol decreased in most groups except one, and dietary intake of energy, fat, and cholesterol decreased across all groups.
population_specificity: 71 free-living men and women with hypercholesterolemia (serum cholesterol greater than the 75th percentile).
effective_dosage: 50 gm/day oat bran (LFLC + OB and OB groups) or 42.5 gm/day processed oat bran (POB group).
study_duration: 4-week intervals (exact total duration not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the metabolic effects of oat bran, specifically its impact on cholesterol levels and other metabolic markers in men with hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: Oat bran significantly reduced serum total cholesterol (13%) and LDL cholesterol (14%) without affecting HDL cholesterol, glucose, insulin, or triglyceride levels. Fecal bile acid excretion increased by 54% on oat bran diets.
population_specificity: Eight men with previously documented hypercholesterolemia.
effective_dosage: 100 g of oat bran included in the test diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits of oat bran biscuits ('Lejfibre') on constipation symptoms in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found that oat bran biscuits significantly improved bowel frequency, stool consistency, and reduced pain during defecation, with no reported side effects. Additionally, participants experienced a notable reduction in mean body weight by the end of the study.
population_specificity: Elderly patients consulting their general practitioner for constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nano-starch and acetylated nano-starch derived from oats for uranium sequestration in wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that both nano-starch and acetylated nano-starch were highly effective in removing uranium, with efficiencies of 97% and 99%, respectively, under optimal conditions. The biosorbents also demonstrated excellent reusability, retaining ~80% and ~84% efficiency over five cycles.
population_specificity: Not specified (wastewater treatment context).
effective_dosage: 0.75 g/25 mL for nano-starch, 1.00 g/25 mL for acetylated nano-starch.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how humic acid (HA) application at varying irrigation amounts affects β-glucan content in naked oats during post-anthesis stages.
results_summary: HA application increased β-glucan content in grains at 5, 15, and 25 days post-anthesis (DPA), with the highest increase (16%) at 5 DPA. Sucrose distribution in leaves and panicles at 10 DPA influenced β-glucan content at 15 DPA, with leaves showing a positive effect and panicles a negative effect.
population_specificity: Naked oats (specific human or animal population not specified).
effective_dosage: HA applied once during booting and anthesis stages at irrigation amounts of 60 mm, 120 mm, and 180 mm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial and cancer-preventive properties of β-glucan nanoparticles (GNP) derived from oats.
results_summary: The study found that GNP exhibited significant antibacterial activity and induced apoptosis in MCF-7 cancer cell lines, with an IC50 value of 50.41-59.34 µg/ml, indicating potent anticancer effects. The nanoparticles also showed selective cytotoxicity towards cancer cells, suggesting potential for targeted therapy.
population_specificity: MCF-7 cancer cell lines (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the hypocholesterolemic effects of beta-glucan in oat bran and oatmeal on adults with elevated LDL-C levels.
results_summary: Oat bran at 56 g and 84 g doses significantly reduced LDL-C levels (15.9% and 11.5%, respectively), outperforming oatmeal at equivalent doses. The study confirmed a dose-dependent reduction in LDL-C levels attributable to beta-glucan.
population_specificity: 156 adults with LDL-C levels above 4.14 mmol/L (160 mg/dL) or between 3.37 and 4.14 mmol/L (130-160 mg/dL) with multiple risk factors.
effective_dosage: 28 g, 56 g, and 84 g of oat bran or oatmeal (dry weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how agronomic treatments (chemical plant protection and nitrogen fertilization) affect the nutritional composition of two oat genotypes (hulless and hulled).
results_summary: Agronomic treatments altered fatty acid profiles, tocopherol content, and macronutrient/micronutrient levels in oat grain. Plant health increased unsaturated fatty acids and potassium, while nitrogen fertilization reduced unsaturated fatty acids, potassium, and copper but increased saturated fatty acids, calcium, and manganese. Hulless oats showed stronger correlations between desirable compounds and treatments.
population_specificity: Oat genotypes (hulless and hulled) under agronomic treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of aluminum chloride and UV-C light on the germination and initial growth of white oat seedlings.
results_summary: High concentrations of aluminum chloride (≥100 mg/L) significantly reduced germination and seedling growth in white oats. UV-C light exposure did not mitigate the toxic effects of aluminum.
population_specificity: White oat seeds (Avena sativa)
effective_dosage: Aluminum chloride (100, 200, 300, 400, or 500 mg/L); UV-C light (0.85 and 3.42 kJ m-2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality changes in potato-oat composite dough and its products during freeze-thaw cycles to determine optimal storage conditions.
results_summary: The study found that freeze-thaw cycles reduced water content and altered protein structures in the dough, negatively affecting sensory properties after three cycles. The dough's quality significantly deteriorated by the fourth cycle, with changes in rheological properties and water state.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on composite dough).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically evaluate the health benefits of oats, including effects on all-cause mortality, cardiovascular and diabetes risk, blood lipids, glucose, blood pressure, weight management, and gut health.
results_summary: Oats showed beneficial effects on blood cholesterol, blood glucose (especially postprandial in diabetic and non-diabetic subjects), blood pressure in prehypertensive individuals, and weight management in overweight individuals. Limited epidemiological data suggested possible benefits for all-cause mortality and incident diabetes, but cardiovascular effects were unclear.
population_specificity: Diabetic and non-diabetic subjects, prehypertensive individuals, overweight individuals, and general populations with varying oat consumption levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how water activity and temperature stress affect the production of trichothecenes and their conjugates in oats.
results_summary: The study found that HT-2-glucoside concentrations were highest at 0.98 aw and 20°C, while DAS concentrations were highest at 0.95 aw and 20°C. Emerging mycotoxins increased with higher water activity and temperature in naturally contaminated oats.
population_specificity: Contaminated oat samples

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a cover crop mixture (self-grown oats and white mustard) on soil biogenity and carbon sequestration in organic farming in Serbia.
results_summary: The study found that the cover crop mixture significantly increased soil biogenity, including higher microbial counts, soil respiration, and microbial biomass carbon compared to the control. This suggests improved soil health and carbon sequestration potential.
population_specificity: Organic farming soils in Serbia.
study_duration: A few years (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of oats combined with rapeseed cake on ruminal methane emission and lactational performance in dairy cows.
results_summary: The study found that feeding rapeseed cake with oats reduced methane production by 9.4% and methane intensity by 11.7% compared to rapeseed meal with barley, while maintaining milk yield and improving feed efficiency.
population_specificity: Twelve lactating Nordic Red cows (4 primiparous, 8 multiparous).
effective_dosage: 6 kg/d for multiparous cows, 5 kg/d for primiparous cows (pellet containing oats and rapeseed cake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pathogenicity and virulence of Phytophthora sansomeana on oats and other crops, focusing on symptomatic and asymptomatic effects.
results_summary: Oats showed no significant reduction in total plant biomass and harbored the least amount of P. sansomeana DNA, indicating resistance compared to other crops tested. The study also found that all P. sansomeana isolates were sensitive to tested oomicides.
population_specificity: Agricultural crop species (oats, corn, wheat, soybean, dry bean, winter cereal rye) in Michigan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of daily oat-based product consumption on serum lipids and cardiovascular events in patients with dyslipidemia.
results_summary: Oat-based products significantly reduced LDL-C and TC levels but had little effect on HDL-C, TG, or major cardiovascular events. Adverse events were mostly mild gastrointestinal issues like diarrhea and nausea.
population_specificity: Patients with dyslipidemia (1731 subjects across 17 trials).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied by product type: oat β-glucan-based, oat bran-based, or wholegrain oat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of pulsed electric field (PEF) treatment on oat seedling growth and stress tolerance under drought and salinity conditions.
results_summary: PEF application improved root and shoot growth in oat seedlings, particularly when applied at a later germination stage. Under salinity stress, PEF enhanced shoot growth, but no effect was observed under drought stress.
population_specificity: Oat seedlings at two growth stages (0.2 cm root emergence and 0.4 cm shoot emergence).
effective_dosage: PEF treatment (99 monopolar, rectangular pulses, 10 µs each, 13 Hz frequency, 2250 V/cm electric field strength).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how oat supplementation during antibiotic exposure influences gut microbiome dysbiosis compared to other dietary timings and dextrose.
results_summary: Oat administration during amoxicillin challenge provided greater protection against antibiotic-induced dysbiosis (AID) than other oat diet timings or dextrose. Oats reduced Firmicutes elimination and shifted gut microbial metabolism toward stress management.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro model based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Avenanthramides (Avns) from oats as neuroprotective agents by modulating the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway in neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Avns exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptotic properties, which modulate PI3K/AKT signaling to enhance neuronal survival, reduce oxidative stress, and improve cognitive function in neurodegenerative diseases. The review highlights the need for further clinical exploration to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Neurodegenerative disease models (e.g., Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the chronic effects of oats on postprandial bile acids, gut microbiota, and cardiometabolic health biomarkers compared to a control (cornflakes).
results_summary: Oats significantly decreased postprandial serum insulin and C-peptide responses, indicating beneficial effects on postprandial glycemia, but did not modulate gut microbiota composition.
population_specificity: 61 volunteers (mean age 52 ± 12 years; BMI 24.8 ± 3.4 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Avena sativa (oat extracts) on cognitive function in healthy adults.
results_summary: Acute ingestion of Avena sativa improved accuracy and speed of cognitive performance, while short-term chronic supplementation showed significant cognitive benefits. Long-term chronic supplementation did not yield improvements.
population_specificity: Healthy adults
study_duration: Varied (acute and chronic, with chronic studies including short-term and long-term durations)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of feeding different proportions of oat hay and alfalfa hay on the growth performance and meat quality of Albas goats.
results_summary: Increasing alfalfa content in the diet reduced daily weight gain but improved antioxidant activity in goat meat, while an oat-hay mixture enhanced growth performance. The gut microbiota, particularly Bacteroidales_unclassified and Clostridium, was strongly correlated with antioxidant markers.
population_specificity: Albas goats
effective_dosage: Four treatment groups: whole oat (OAT), oat-alfalfa 3:7 (OA73), oat-alfalfa 7:3 (OA37), and whole alfalfa (Alfalfa)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate nutrient transfer from cattle manure to soil and oats, and assess changes in microbial community composition in oat rhizospheres.
results_summary: Cattle manure improved nutrient absorption (11.79% N, 7.89% P by oats) and soil sequestration, enhanced root growth, and promoted beneficial microbial communities while inhibiting harmful fungal genera.
population_specificity: Oat plants grown under simulated cattle manure deposition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an oat product containing 3 g of β-Glucan could reduce systemic chronic inflammation (SCI) and improve clinical outcomes related to healthy aging, as measured by the Inflammatory Age® (iAge®) metric.
results_summary: The oat product significantly reduced iAge® in subjects with elevated baseline levels (>49.6 iAge® years) within two weeks, primarily driven by decreased Eotaxin-1 protein levels, while the rice control group showed no change. The effects were independent of gender, BMI, or chronological age.
population_specificity: Adults with borderline high cholesterol.
study_duration: Effects observed as early as two weeks post-treatment (total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal extraction conditions for oat avenanthramides (AVAs) and evaluate their inhibitory effects on advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) and reactive oxygen species.
results_summary: The study found that AVAs, particularly AVA 2f, effectively inhibited AGE formation and trapped α-dicarbonyl compounds, with AVA 2f showing superior antioxidant activity compared to AVA 2p. The effects were dose-dependent.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using a glucose-casein simulation system)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of oats and their products in regulating blood lipid levels for the treatment of dyslipidaemia.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that oat β-glucan may help lower cholesterol, but there is no conclusive evidence for oats' efficacy in treating dyslipidaemia. The study proposes a protocol for future research to address this gap.
population_specificity: Not specified (study is a protocol for future research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the mechanism and therapeutic effect of Avenanthramide C (a compound in oats) in reducing inflammatory responses in pediatric pneumonia.
results_summary: Avenanthramide C reduced inflammation and pyroptosis in pediatric pneumonia models by modulating PI3K/AKT/Nrf2/ROS signaling, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for inflammatory diseases.
population_specificity: Pediatric pneumonia models (vivo and vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether non-fatal overdose followed the same pattern as fatal overdose during opioid agonist treatment (OAT), comparing the first 4 weeks of treatment and cessation to the remainder of treatment time.
results_summary: The study found that retention on OAT was protective against overdose, with the highest non-fatal overdose risk at treatment initiation and the highest fatal overdose risk in the first month after cessation. The remainder time in OAT had the lowest incidence of overdose for all outcomes.
population_specificity: People with a history of opioid agonist treatment in New South Wales.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of biochar from invasive weeds (Parthenium hysterophorus L. and Lantana camara L.) combined with inorganic fertilizers on oats' growth, fodder yield, quality, and soil microbial activity.
results_summary: The study found that 75% RDF with 10 t/ha Lantana camara L. biochar significantly increased green and dry fodder yield, crude protein, and soil microbial activity while reducing acid and neutral detergent fiber compared to 100% RDF. The treatment also improved soil health metrics like microbial biomass carbon and dehydrogenase activity.
population_specificity: Oats (Avena sativa L.) in a pot experiment.
effective_dosage: 75% RDF with 2.5, 5.0, or 10 t/ha biochar (Parthenium hysterophorus L. or Lantana camara L.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine an evidence-based link between oat consumption and inflammatory markers through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found no significant alterations in systemic inflammatory markers after oat consumption overall, but observed a significant decrease in CRP levels in subjects with health complications and a reduction in IL-6 levels in those with dyslipidemia. These effects may be attributed to avenanthramide and β-glucan.
population_specificity: Subjects with one or more health complications, including dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the genetic response of oats in a high-selenium environment and identify key genes involved in selenate metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that selenate treatment significantly altered gene expression in oats, with 7,226 unigenes upregulated and 2,618 downregulated. Key genes involved in selenate metabolism, such as APS and APR, showed over 1,000-fold upregulation, suggesting a robust genetic response to selenium exposure.
population_specificity: Oats (Avena sativa) treated with sodium selenate in a laboratory setting.
effective_dosage: Not specified (24-hour treatment with sodium selenate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of barley versus different types of oats (hulled, dehulled, and a mixture) on milk production, methane emissions, ruminal fermentation, digestibility, and energy utilization in dairy cows.
results_summary: Oat diets increased milk and energy-corrected milk yield compared to barley, reduced methane intensity by 5.7%, and improved feed efficiency, but dehulling oats did not significantly enhance production performance. Digestibility and energy utilization improved with increasing inclusion of dehulled oats, though methane emissions also increased linearly.
population_specificity: Sixteen Nordic Red dairy cows, 80 ± 4.6 days in milk, average body weight 624 ± 91.8 kg.
effective_dosage: Grass silage and experimental concentrate (60:40 forage-to-concentrate ratio on dry matter basis) fed ad libitum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how methyl jasmonate (MeJA) and abscisic acid (ABA) treatments affect avenanthramide production in germinating oats.
results_summary: MeJA and ABA treatments significantly increased avenanthramide content in germinating oats, with co-treatment showing synergistic effects. Gene expression analysis revealed upregulation of key enzymes, particularly AsHHT5, enhancing avenanthramide biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Germinating oats (Avena sativa L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of irrigation levels on white oat agronomic performance and assess the accuracy of the CERES-Barley model in simulating oat growth and yield, as well as identifying optimal sowing dates for different irrigation levels.
results_summary: Deficit irrigation linearly reduced white oat agronomic performance. The CERES-Barley model accurately estimated oat yield (R² = 0.86), enabling long-term simulations that identified optimal sowing dates—cooler periods (May-June) for higher irrigation levels and wetter periods (March-April) for deficit irrigation.
population_specificity: White oat (Avena sativa L.) crops in southeastern Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the long-term outcomes of youth with depression or subsyndromal bipolar disorder after participation in clinical trials involving omega-3 fatty acids and psychoeducational psychotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that participants' mood severity, executive functioning, and global functioning remained better than baseline, though depressive symptoms increased post-RCT. Many participants continued or started omega-3 or psychotherapy, suggesting consumer satisfaction.
population_specificity: Youth with depression (n=25) or subsyndromal bipolar disorder (n=13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of replacing barley with oats on methane emissions, rumen fermentation, diet digestibility, milk production, and energy utilization in dairy cows.
results_summary: Increasing oat inclusion linearly reduced methane emissions and methane intensity without affecting milk yield or energy balance, though it decreased organic matter and fiber digestibility. The study concluded oats could replace barley to mitigate methane emissions without adverse productivity effects.
population_specificity: Lactating Nordic Red dairy cows fed a grass silage-based diet.
effective_dosage: Grain supplements (30% of diet DM) included 100% barley, 67% barley + 33% oats, 33% barley + 67% oats, and 100% oats.
study_duration: 21-day periods in a 4 × 4 Latin square design.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the frequency and incidence rates of non-fatal overdose (NFOD) hospital separations among opioid-dependent individuals with a history of opioid agonist treatment (OAT).
results_summary: The study found that NFOD hospital stays were relatively frequent among opioid-dependent individuals, with higher opioid NFOD incidence in women and younger age groups. The cohort accounted for significant proportions of opioid, sedative, stimulant, and alcohol-related NFOD episodes in NSW.
population_specificity: Opioid-dependent individuals with a history of opioid agonist treatment (OAT) in New South Wales, Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of whole grain oats on preventing insulin resistance induced by a high-fat diet in rats using a metabolomic approach.
results_summary: Whole grain oats regulated body weight, blood glucose, blood lipid, and inflammatory response, preventing insulin resistance, with 50% oat replacement being effective. Metabolomics identified six differential metabolites linked to energy, amino acid, and lipid metabolism pathways.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced insulin resistance rat model (60 rats).
effective_dosage: 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% replacement of sucrose and starch with whole grain oats powder in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the first clinical case of oral mite anaphylaxis (OMA) due to the consumption of oat flakes contaminated with mites.
results_summary: The study reported a case of anaphylaxis in a patient after consuming oat flakes contaminated with mites, confirmed by skin prick tests and mite analysis. It identified Blattisocius keegani and Suidasia pontifica as the contaminating mites.
population_specificity: 39-year-old female patient in Panama City, Panama.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and long-term quality of life and health effects of oat consumption in dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) patients on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that 82% of DH patients consumed oats without differences in long-term illnesses, complications, or medication use compared to non-consumers. Oat consumers reported better quality of life and fewer gastrointestinal symptoms (4% vs 19%).
population_specificity: 312 long-term treated dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of the physical form of oats (ground vs. whole) in calf starter on the expression of key hepatic genes related to gluconeogenesis, β-oxidation, and acute phase proteins in preweaned dairy calves.
results_summary: The study found that the physical form of oats did not affect the expression of gluconeogenic and β-oxidation enzymes but did increase the expression of the acute phase protein haptoglobin in calves fed whole oats. Lower rumen pH was associated with upregulated expression of certain enzymes.
population_specificity: Preweaned dairy calves (5-7 weeks old).
effective_dosage: Not specified (ground or whole oats in calf starter).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of telephone-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) in older adults with chronic osteoarthritis pain and persistent insomnia.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design and methodology but does not report specific results regarding the effects of the intervention.
population_specificity: Persons aged 60+ with chronic osteoarthritis pain and persistent insomnia who received care within the Kaiser Permanente Washington health care system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different processing methods on cool-season adapted oat grain compared to dry-rolled barley grain when fed as a total mixed ration (TMR) for lactating dairy cows.
results_summary: Rolled oats resulted in the highest milk production and milk fat percentage despite lower dry matter intake compared to pelleted oats. Ruminal fermentation characteristics and total-tract digestibility were mostly similar across treatments, with minor differences in acetate concentrations and starch digestibility.
population_specificity: Lactating Holstein cows
effective_dosage: Not specified (fed as part of TMR)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of oats in celiac disease (CD) patients and determine their potential benefits in a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: Pure oats are well-tolerated by most CD patients in moderate amounts (20-25 g/day for children, 50-70 g/day for adults), but caution is advised due to potential sensitivity/toxicity. Oats may improve dietary diversity, taste, and satiety in CD patients.
population_specificity: Celiac disease (CD) patients, including children and adults.
effective_dosage: 20-25 g/day dry rolled oats for children; 50-70 g/day for adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the glycaemic response of whole grain oat kernels and pearled oats cooked under different pressures and assess whether replacing half of the rice in a meal with oats affects acute glycaemic responses.
results_summary: Oat grain-only meals induced lower glucose levels, peak values, and smaller glucose excursions compared to rice, with glycaemic indexes ranging from 51 to 58. Mixed oat-rice meals showed less pronounced effects, though whole grain oats with normal pressure cooking still provided favourable glycaemic outcomes.
population_specificity: Ten healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of increasing nitrogen application on oat yield, grain quality, and metabolite profiles, focusing on nutritional quality and metabolic responses.
results_summary: Nitrogen application significantly increased grain yield and β-glucan content, with notable metabolic changes including upregulated amino acid and protein levels, decreased organic acids, and impacts on phenolic compounds. The study also developed a rapid metabolite profiling method, identifying distinct metabolic phenotypes among oat varieties.
population_specificity: Four winter oat varieties (Mascani, Tardis, Balado, Gerald) grown in a controlled nitrogen response trial.
effective_dosage: Nitrogen treatments ranged from 0 to 200 kg N ha-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the risks and adverse outcomes associated with opioid agonist treatment (OAT) and develop a risk-prediction model to inform its expansion in the USA.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results about Oats (Avena sativa) but focused on opioid agonist treatment (OAT) outcomes, including mortality, hospitalizations, and treatment cessation.
population_specificity: People seeking opioid agonist treatment in New South Wales, Australia, between 2001 and 2017.

study_goal: To evaluate the long-term validity and safety of pure oats in the treatment of children with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in clinical, serologic, or intestinal permeability variables between children consuming oats and those on a placebo, concluding that pure nonreactive oat products are a safe dietary choice for children with celiac disease.
population_specificity: Children with biopsy-proven celiac disease on a gluten-free diet for ≥2 years.
effective_dosage: 15-40 g of purified nonreactive oats daily, age-dependent.
study_duration: Two consecutive 6-month periods separated by a 3-month washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of carbohydrate-hydrolysing enzymes on the release of phenolic compounds in oat fermentation with Monascus anka.
results_summary: The study found that oat powder treated with crude enzyme from fermented oats showed a significant increase in phenolic content, particularly ferulic acid in the insoluble fraction and vanillic acid in the soluble fraction. The crude enzyme treatment damaged the oat cell wall structure, facilitating phenolic release.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term safety and quality-of-life impact of oats in celiac patients on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in dietary adherence, symptoms, serological markers, or adverse health outcomes between oat consumers and non-consumers. Oat consumers showed better quality-of-life scores in certain SF-36 domains.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients on a gluten-free diet (n=869).
study_duration: Median duration of gluten-free diet was 10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a formula diet supplemented with oats fibers versus a low glycemic and insulinemic diet on intrahepatic lipid content and metabolic parameters in obese patients with fatty liver disease.
results_summary: Both diets reduced BMI and improved liver function, but the oats-supplemented diet showed greater reductions in intrahepatic lipid content and blood pressure compared to the control diet.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI > 30 kg/m²) with signs of fatty liver disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified (commercially available formula diet supplemented with oats fibers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of power ultrasound on the nutritional properties and microstructure of germinated oats, focusing on health-promoting metabolites like GABA and phenolic compounds.
results_summary: Power ultrasound treatment (25 kHz for 5 min after soaking) significantly enhanced GABA, alanine, succinic acid, total phenolic content, and total avenanthramides in germinated oats, while also improving antioxidant capacities and free sugars. The study also examined microstructural changes in oat groats using ESEM and Micro-CT.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or plant-based study, no human participants mentioned).
effective_dosage: 5 minutes of power ultrasound treatment after soaking.
study_duration: Germination periods ranged from 24 to 96 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oats consumption on lipid parameters in mildly hypercholesterolemic Asian Indians.
results_summary: Daily consumption of 70g of oats (providing 3g of soluble fiber) led to significant reductions in total cholesterol (8.1%) and LDL cholesterol (11.6%) compared to the control group over 28 days. The study concluded that oats have beneficial effects on lipid parameters in this population.
population_specificity: Mildly hypercholesterolemic Asian Indians living in India.
effective_dosage: 70g of oats twice daily (as porridge and upma).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the urine metabolomic profile at the time of methotrexate (MTX) administration could predict the drug's clearance and treatment-related toxicity.
results_summary: The study found that urinary metabolomics could predict individual MTX clearance using a set of 28 metabolites, but it did not distinguish between patients with or without delayed elimination or toxicity. The model included endogenous organic anions dependent on OAT function.
population_specificity: Adult patients treated for lymphoid malignancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively study the biotransformation of HT-2 and T-2 toxins in oats and identify their metabolites and mobility within plant tissues.
results_summary: The study identified 16 HT-2 and 17 T-2 metabolites, including novel glycosylated and hydroxylated forms, with HT2-3-O-β-d-glucoside as the major detoxification product. Parent toxins showed negligible mobility, while HT2-3-O-β-d-glucoside was partially transported within the plant.
population_specificity: Oats (non-treated plant tissues)
study_duration: One day after treatment (for rapid metabolite formation assessment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oat consumption on blood glucose, HOMA-IR index, lipid profile, weight, and BMI in adults.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in all anthropometric and biochemical parameters, while the control group had no significant improvements and even increased blood glucose and HOMA-IR. Oats demonstrated beneficial effects on cardiovascular health by improving lipid and glycemic profiles.
population_specificity: Adults aged 22-60 years, users of a health service in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil (58.5% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant mechanisms of colloidal oatmeal and assess its clinical efficacy in improving skin conditions like dryness, scaling, and itch.
results_summary: Colloidal oatmeal extracts reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines in vitro, and the topical lotion significantly improved skin dryness, scaling, roughness, and itch intensity in clinical subjects.
population_specificity: Twenty-nine healthy female subjects with mild to moderate itch and moderate to severe dry skin on their lower legs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of irradiated fresh frozen osteochondral allografts (Mega-OATS technique) for treating large osteochondral defects in the knee.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in Lysholm and IKDC scores over a 2-year follow-up, with radiographic union observed in all patients by 3 months and osseous integration in 8 out of 9 patients by 1 year. Adverse events included graft subsidence in one patient and subchondral cystic changes in another.
population_specificity: Nine patients (mean age 32.1±6.6) with large osteochondral defects of the femoral condyles, primarily due to osteochondrosis dissecans or trauma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the transfer of nitrogen (N) and carbon (C) from mungbean rhizodeposition to oats in an intercropping system and its impact on soil nutrient availability.
results_summary: The study found that intercropping mungbean with oats increased the release of N and C from mungbean rhizodeposition, with a small percentage transferred to oats and a large percentage remaining in the soil, potentially benefiting subsequent crops.
population_specificity: Mungbean and oat plants in an intercropping system.
study_duration: Harvested at pod setting and maturity stages (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of omega-3 supplementation (Ω3) and psychoeducational psychotherapy (PEP), alone and in combination, on executive functioning (EF) in youth with mood disorders.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation (alone or combined with PEP) significantly improved executive functioning compared to placebo, with moderate to large effect sizes. PEP monotherapy showed negligible effects.
population_specificity: Youths (95 participants) with depression or bipolar disorder not otherwise specified/cyclothymic disorder.
effective_dosage: 1.87 g Ω3 total daily (mostly eicosapentaenoic acid), given as two capsules twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review intervention studies investigating the effects of oats or oat bran on risk factors for bowel diseases, including colorectal cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, and coeliac disease.
results_summary: Most studies in coeliac disease patients showed no negative effects of uncontaminated oat consumption. Oats or oat bran increased stool weight and reduced constipation in healthy volunteers, but no specific effect compared to other cereals was proven. Limited evidence suggested small benefits for ulcerative colitis and no clear protective effect on colorectal adenomas.
population_specificity: Adults with coeliac disease, ulcerative colitis, history of colorectal adenomas, and healthy volunteers.
effective_dosage: Up to 100 g/d of uncontaminated oats for coeliac disease patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how iron oxide nanoparticles (IONPs) mitigate the uptake and adverse effects of polystyrene nanoplastics (PSNPs) on Perilla frutescens growth.
results_summary: IONPs reduced PSNPs accumulation in Perilla by 46.15% in roots and 24.83% in stems, improved plant growth (20.40% height, 34.22% biomass), enhanced photosynthetic parameters, and reduced oxidative stress by upregulating photosystem and flavonoid synthesis genes.
population_specificity: Perilla frutescens (plant model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fermented Perilla frutescens (FPF) on cognitive impairment caused by sleep deprivation and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: FPF improved cognitive impairment in sleep-deprived mice by enhancing memory performance, reducing oxidative stress, and restoring BDNF levels and related signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to sleep deprivation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effect and underlying mechanism of perilla frutescens leaf extracts (PLE) in treating acute lung injury (ALI) by focusing on its anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: PLE significantly reduced LPS-induced lung damage, improved respiratory function, and increased survival rates in mice. It suppressed inflammatory cytokines and inhibited KAT2A expression, demonstrating a dose-dependent anti-inflammatory effect.
population_specificity: Mice with LPS-induced ALI and BEAS-2B cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the active ingredients in perilla and systematically summarize the mechanism by which perilla oil regulates lipid metabolism to expand its potential health applications.
results_summary: The study found that perilla contains beneficial ingredients like fatty acids, flavonoids, and phenolic acids, which enhance intestinal health and help manage metabolic diseases. Perilla oil was highlighted as a promising agent for regulating lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Not specified (review study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of perilla supplementation in different forms (seed, oil, and formaldehyde-treated oil) on milk fatty acid composition, milk quality, and ruminal fermentation in lactating goats.
results_summary: Perilla supplementation increased beneficial fatty acids (CLA, omega-3 PUFAs) in milk, with the protected form (PPO) showing the greatest effects. It did not adversely affect performance, ruminal fermentation, or blood parameters, though PO decreased milk fat while PPO increased it.
population_specificity: Lactating goats
effective_dosage: 44.7 g/kg (seed, containing 20 g/kg oil), 20 g/kg (oil), 20 g/kg (formaldehyde-treated oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of L-perilla alcohol (L-POH) in treating hypoxic pulmonary hypertension (HPAH) using network pharmacology and experimental verification.
results_summary: L-POH was found to relax pulmonary arterioles by acting on vascular smooth muscle, opening ATP-sensitive potassium channels, and inhibiting extracellular Ca²⁺ influx. It also inhibited hypoxia-induced proliferation of pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells and promoted apoptosis, likely through modulation of Bax, p-JAK2, p-STAT3, Bcl-2, and cyclinA2 protein expression.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and ex vivo experimental models were used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine why tetraploid perilla seeds have higher α-linolenic acid (18:3) content and explored the genetic mechanisms behind fatty acid composition.
results_summary: The study found that gamma irradiation and CRISPR/Cas9 knockout of FAD3 genes in tetraploid perilla altered fatty acid composition, increasing 18:2 and decreasing 18:3. The higher 18:3 content in tetraploid perilla was attributed to the acquisition of two FAD3 copies through hybridization.
population_specificity: Tetraploid and diploid perilla plants (Perilla frutescens and Perilla citriodora).
